history.content:
Don't do anything; read @5947.

You will most likely be fine: classes generally clear 10% of the waitlist and #7 is definitely under 10%. Since you can go to any discussion, you should look for another lab to enroll in that might be open. Do not swap labs on CalCentral right now @5947 - I don't think you will be able to, anyway, so there's nothing you can do at the moment.

children.subject:
No, I don't think that is right. If you are correct, then everybody with a larger number than you would be similarly out of luck - then what would be the point of a waitlist? The equivalent of 10% of the class gets off the waitlist, not by section. 

This is further explained here:

What are the chances that I get into the class when I’m on the waitlist? Waitlist processing has not changed with the new system. The system checks for open seats twice a day on the primary component waitlist (lecture, for example), and checks to see if there are open seats on the secondary component (discussion, lab, etc) waitlist. If you are first on the primary waitlist and both the primary and secondary section that you have enrolled in are available, you will be enrolled in the class, given that you meet all requirements (such as requirements for the class, enrollment phase, have no holds, etc). If there’s no space in the secondary section you have selected, you will be bypassed and the process will continue to the next person until all primary component seats are filled. Note that your position on the secondary component waitlist does not matter as long as there are open seats in the section.

10% is a rule of thumb, that is usually applied per class. On average, it would still be a similar proportion per section, so you could try applying it per section, but you should expect much higher variance and thus lower reliability for this approximation.

But if you're applying it to the whole class, you should be using your position on the entire class's waitlist, and not just for your particular section.
As far as I know,  the waitlist is processed by section and #7 is not under 10% of the section size. In order to enroll,  7 students in my section need to drop.

history.content:
Hi there,

I am a senior who is on the waitlist for EE16A. I waitlisted for EE16A during Phase II.

I am currently position 7 on the waitlist for my lab/discussion and I am worried that I will not get in (since waitlist processing is done by section instead of by lecture).

Do you have any advice on what I can do in this situation?

I know you are getting a ton of questions like this right now, so thank you for your time and sorry for the trouble!
history.subject: EE16A Waitlist as a Senior
